articles.headline: Democrats Face Deepening Peril as Republicans Seize on Inflation Fears
articles.snippet: Economists warn that a blitz of midterm election campaign ads could push consumer prices even higher.
articles.abstract: Economists warn that a blitz of midterm election campaign ads could push consumer prices even higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Triple-digit gasoline bills. Bulging hamburger prices. A Fourth of July holiday that broke the bank.

articles.headline: Facts Were Sparse on an Abortion Case. But That Didn’t Stop the Attacks.
articles.snippet: The story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio became the focus of a heated political debate that played out in the news media.
articles.abstract: The story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio became the focus of a heated political debate that played out in the news media.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two weeks, the story of a 10-year-old Ohio girl who was raped and crossed state lines to get an abortion became a flash point in the national abortion debate. President Biden and other Democrats argued that it showed the harm resulting from the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade.

articles.headline: China’s Economy Hits a Slump as Covid Policy Takes a Toll
articles.snippet: High unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending during lockdowns are putting pressure on Beijing in a year when officials are focused on projecting stability.
articles.abstract: High unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending during lockdowns are putting pressure on Beijing in a year when officials are focused on projecting stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: When countries around the world have stumbled in the face of pandemic headwinds, China has often stood apart, seemingly impervious to financial pressures that undermined growth.

articles.headline: Germany Hopes to Outrace a Russian Gas Cutoff and Bone Cold Winter
articles.snippet: Europe’s largest economy and key energy hub still depends on gas supplies now ensnared in conflict. Here’s how Germany is preparing and what is at stake.
articles.abstract: Europe’s largest economy and key energy hub still depends on gas supplies now ensnared in conflict. Here’s how Germany is preparing and what is at stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian natural gas has fired the furnaces that create molten stainless steel at Clemens Schmees’s family foundry since 1961, when his father set up shop in a garage in the western part of Germany.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Voters See a Bad Economy, Even if They’re Doing OK
articles.snippet: A New York Times/Siena poll shows remarkable pessimism despite the labor market’s resilience. That could be costly for the Democrats, and the economy.
articles.abstract: A New York Times/Siena poll shows remarkable pessimism despite the labor market’s resilience. That could be costly for the Democrats, and the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fastest inflation in four decades has Americans feeling dour about the economy, even as their own finances have, so far, held up relatively well.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Lydia DePillis
